content.value: There comes a time in a game's life cycle where you have to start inviting the dreaded games journalists over to actually play the thing. The relationship between dev and journalist can be a tense one. Often, these are quite strictly controlled affairs, with a PR figure looming in the corner, nodding or shaking their head to indicate what information should be divulged and what should or should not be said.
Our band of indie heroes hate all that nonsense; when games journalist Matt Lees came over to play, Sean sat down with him, gave him a controller and basically told him to get cracking.

Despite the laid back and friendly attitudes from both parties, however, there was still tension in the air as everyone wondered how the game (and the then in development iOS version) would stand up to scrutiny.
Sean looks on as Matt plays the prototype of 'Joe Danger Touch!' on the iPhone.
Sean is watching Matt play here to make sure that the design is doing its job; he wants to see if Matt 'gets it' without having to step in and tell him how he should play the game.
